newsitem.title: GABON: African leaders fail to achieve Congo breakthrough.
newsitem.headline: African leaders fail to achieve Congo breakthrough.

text.p: African heads of state and U.N. special envoy Mohamed Sahnoun said on Monday that they had failed to achieve a breakthrough in a bloody power struggle in the Congo Republic but would carry on trying for a solution.

A communique issued at the end of a day of bilateral meetings with the representatives of the warring parties and of Congolese mediators said that they had not yet identified sufficient common ground to promote dialogue and conciliation.
Gabon's veteran president, Omar Bongo, hosted the talks with the help of the presidents of Chad, Mali and the Central African Republic.

"The international mediating committee on the Congo crisis notes that for the moment it has not been able to bring the interested parties round to a certain number of proposals which it thinks would help promote an environment for dialogue and consultation," the communiqu said.

Senegalese Foreign Minister Moustapha Niasse read the communique, in which the committee called for an immediate and lasting ceasefire in Brazzaville, the embattled capital of the former French colony.

Supporters of President Pascal Lissouba and his predecessor former Marxist military leader Denis Sassou Nguesso have engaged in bloody political and ethnic fighting there since June 5 when troops surrounded Sassou Nguesso's home as part of a crackdown on private militia ahead of a July 27 presidential election.
